loans.name: Eseza

texts.en:
Eseza T. lives in the Kisasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.   She also takes care of additional family members. She sells second-hand clothes in Kisaasi market and sells retail to all categories of people.  She buys second-hand clothes from Owino market  and uses public transport to and from Owino market.  

Eseza has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes.     She doesn’t have any additional source of income. She has been in this business for ten years and works six days a week. The main business challenges for Eseza include transportation and the rainy season.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing second-hand clothes.      

She decided to join MCDT because of the low interest charged. Eseza lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and food.

loans.use: to buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Juje

texts.en:
Juje B. is from  Maloro, Tangub City. He is 31 years old. Juje is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Juje owns & operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing vulcanizing services to local community members. Juje has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juje joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juje has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Juje is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Juje from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Turesian Ole

texts.en:
Turesian Ole N. is 49 years old. He is married to Meteu Nkawatei and he is the father of four children. Turesian is a wheat farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last ten years.

He learned about KADET LTD through a friend who is a KADET LTD registered client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan which he is planning to spend buying pesticide and fertilizer for his already growing wheat. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan by reinvesting in the farm and planting a bigger piece of land with wheat.

Turesian's dream is to practice large-scale farming and attain financial independence. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to buy pesticide and fertilizer for his already growing wheat

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma S. is from Prenza, Tangub City. She is 43 years old. Emma is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Emma owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Emma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Emma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Iriel

texts.en:
Iriel T. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 26 years old. Iriel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Iriel owns & operates a business venture providing a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating boat-ride services. Iriel has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Iriel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Iriel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase an additional vehicle for the business. Iriel is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to repair existing engine. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Iriel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing engine

loans.name: Olivett Achieng

texts.en:
Olivett is 30 years old and married to Kennedy Oruko, who is a doctor. They have two children: Gladwell Atieno, who is 4 years old, and Bramwel Oruko, who is 2 years old. They live in Maseno town which is in vihiga district. Olivett runs a beauty salon and has been doing so for the last four years and she confesses that the business is doing well.

She is applying for her first loan with KADET LTD after she was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who is already a client. The loan will enable her to buy some salon products like shampoos, towels and hair chemicals. Her salon is situated in an urban setup and most of her clients are university students.

She hopes to establish a full beauty parlor in the area to capture the large market demand and be able to build a permanent house. When her business is stable she will be able to see to it that her children get the best education available.

loans.use: To buy salon products to add to her stock

loans.name: Bendicto Kuruk

texts.en:
Bendicto Kuruk A. is a 26-year-old man. He is married to Naomi Eyanae and they have a child of 3 years old. They live in Eldoret town. Bendicto operates a motor-bike transport service, which is how he earns his income. He has been in this business for the past year and a half with an income of 8,000 Kenyan shillings (Kshs) per month.

Bendicto was introduced to KADET LTD. by a credit officer and he is applying for his first loan of Kshs.5,000. With this loan, he plans to purchase bicycles.

He hopes with the income, he will continue taking loans with KADET LTD. to invest in a boda-boda (bicycle taxi) business and educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase bicycles

loans.name: Samuel Sanguyen

texts.en:
Samuel has been farming for commercial purposes for the last 16 years. He is 34 years old and married to Regina Wangari. They have three children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD. by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to buy maize seedlings for planting. Samuel also has plans to move into the transportation industry in the future by buying his own mini bus. He describes himself as a very hardworking man.

loans.use: To buy maize seedlings for planting

loans.name: Esinyen Lopulumoe

texts.en:
Esinyen Lopulumoe L. is a 31-year-old man married to Anna Amana. They have three children, aged 9, 5 and 2 respectively. They live in Mwanyaka, 1 kilometer from Eldoret town. Esinyen sells charcoal and also repairs bicycles, which is how he earns his income. He has been in this business for the past 10 years with an income of 9,800 Kenyan shillings (Kshs.) per month.

Esinyen was introduced to KADET LTD. by a credit officer and he is applying for his first loan of Kshs.5,000. With this loan, he plans to purchase charcoal and bicycles spare parts.

He hopes that with the income he is going to make, he will purchase a piece of land

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and bicycles spare parts

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 51-year old married man from Lebanon. He has 3 children. He is the main income provider for his family. He has more than thirty years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 1990. He cultivates all kinds of vegetables. He uses plastic tents to grow his products. Today, he is requesting a loan of $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his agriculturA. work and seeds for the coming season. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15%. In the coming years, he hopes to continue the expansion of his business because his work is vitA. for his family.

loans.use: purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work and seeds for the coming season

loans.name: Sarah Chelagat

texts.en:
Sarah Chelagat C. is a 37-year-old lady married to Joseph Chirchir. They have three children, age 20, 18 and 15 respectively. They live in Kamagut, an outer part of Eldoret town. Sarah has a grocery store where she earns her income. She has been in this business for the past five years with an income of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (Kshs.) per month.

Sarah was introduced to KADET LTD. by a friend and she is applying for her fourth loan of Kshs. 30,000 with KADET LTD. With this loan, she plans to buy more bananas and cereals.

She hopes to operate a large-scale grocery shop, where she can be able to supply to hotels and sell the best quality items to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas and cereals

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica N. lives in the Mulago neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of her sister’s children. She lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication and feeding the family.

Monica has a business selling bitenge (African wear: a single piece of cloth worn like a sarong). She has been in this business for seven years, and she works six days a week. Monica sells this African attire in a shop which she rents for 40,000 Ugandan shillings per month. She mostly sells retail. She also generates additional income through poultry farming.

Monica has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bitenge. The main business challenges for Monica include seasonality and transportation.

Monica’s goal and aspiration is to construct her own house.

loans.use: To buy more bitenge to sell

loans.name: Francis Kingee

texts.en:
Francis has been farming in Naivasha town for the last seven years. He is 32 years old, is married to Alice K., and has two children.

Francis was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He plans to use it to prepare his farm for planting and to buy seedlings to plant.

Francis wants to diversify in the future to start a dairy-farming activity. This will increase his income.

loans.use: To plow his farm and buy seedlings to plant

loans.name: Khalida's Group

texts.en:
Khalida is 35 years old, is married to M. A., and lives in a small city in Pakistan called Chichawatni. She owns a house with four rooms and lives in it with her husband and three children: two boys and a girl. Only her eldest son is able to attend school and he is in 2nd standard. Khalida is a housewife, staying at home to manage her household chores and take care of her family.

Khalida’s husband has a bicycle-repair shop in the market. He repairs bicycles and sells spare parts from the shop as well. His earnings from the business allow him to manage the financial circle of his household and to fulfill the needs of his family. But, as the children are growing, so ultimately their needs will increase and to timely fulfill them he needs to grow his business. This can happen only when he gives better services to his customers and completes their demands on time.

Therefore, Khalida has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband in this regard. With the loan, he will buy more bicycle spare parts and the latest tools for repairing bicycles. Khalida is hopeful that her husband’s business will grow by making this investment in it.

Khalida is a new loan applicant and this is the first time she has applied for a loan from any micro-financial institution. She hopes that it will be a good experience for her and she expects to work with Asasah on a longterm basis.

In the photo, Khalida is the lady who holds a book (called her Asasah Passbook) in her hand.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy the latest repair tools and more bicycle spare parts

loans.name: Kayunga Market Women's Group 1, Kayunga

texts.en:
37-year-old N. Jane of Kayunga Market Women's Group 1, Kayunga, bears testament to the fact that one does not need experience to be an upstart in any business. Going by her own account, all that is needed is a sense of unwavering determination, diligence, pro-activeness, belief, and constant planning. It is now a decade since she took the reins of her vegetable and fruit selling business in Kayunga town market.

Jane is a married mother of two and, along the way, she has not had it easy. In a word, she describes her experiences as chequered, just as in any other business undertaking. That courage of conviction and perseverance, she says, have been her stock in trade.

In a week, Jane makes 60,000 Ugandan shillings and, with this loan, she wants to buy more fresh vegetables and fruits to resell and henceforth make more profits.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh vegetables and fruits to sell

loans.name: Mahpurat's Group

texts.en: Mahpurat M. is the leader of this group. She is 37 and married; her husband is an employee of the highway organization. The couple brings up three children and all of them are schoolboys. Today, Mansura earns her living by working as a youth coordinator on a village board. The family needs a loan in order to buy a lorry-load (truck-load) of sand for house plastering. In the future Mahpurat wants to obtain a car. About the other members of the group: Turgunoi M., 51, is married and her husband is a farmer. Together, the couple brings up a son and two daughters. The son went to work in Russia and the daughters are students. In 1996, when the collective farms broke up. Turgunoi obtained a piece of land and started to cultivate wheat, maize, potatoes and tomatoes. By selling part of the harvest she makes 2,500 soms per month. With the loan, she wants to purchase fertilizers for farming. In the future she wants to build a house for her son. Zebi B., 59, is married with two daughters and a son. Her daughters are married and live separately with their own families and her son works in the police force. Zebi is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband is an employee of the social fund. Zebi resells cattle after fattening and in this way she makes 6,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to start repairing her house. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase a calf to raise. Sadyrbek T. is nineteen years old and is engaged in cattle breeding. He started to breed cattle two years ago with an initial investment of 1,500 soms and now sells cattle after fattening, making 6,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for him to purchase a TV and a DVD player. With the loan, he wants to purchase feed for his cattle. In the future he wants to build a house and open a bakery. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase sand for house plastering

loans.name: Kayunga Market  Women's Group 2, Kayunga

texts.en:
Enraptured is the word to describe 40-year-old W. Ssenoga’s demeanor when he is operating his banana-selling business. He belongs to Kayunga Market Women's Group 2, Kayunga.

Ssenoga’s star has been shining ever-brighter in the last seven years because he has owed it to himself to strike a chord with his clients using not only with his sense of humor, but also his good relationship skills. His success, however, all boils down to his diligence and steadfast entrepreneurial spirit.

This happily married father of six says he began his business with savings from his former fishmonger business. In a week he makes 80,000 Ugandan shillings as profits. He also operates a commercial motorcycle transportation business commonly referred to here as boda-boda.

Ssenoga’s reckoning is that this loan will come in handy to financially help him to buy more bananas to sell and also to pay for repairs to his motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas to sell and also to pay for repairs to his motorcycle

loans.name: Tukoleinho Women's Group, Jinja

texts.en:
39-year-old Monic M. of Tukoleinho Women’s Group, Jinja, carries conviction that she will be an accomplished and successful businesswoman in the future course of time. That is provided she owes it to herself to use the proceeds from this loan in a well-meaning way by purchasing more clothes to resell at her clothes and textile shop in Wabulenga, Jinja.

This married mother of six has been counting on this business for the last twelve years. Combined with her farming business as dependable sources of livelihood, Monic has made strides.

Monic began her clothes and textile business with savings from her farming business and, in a week, she makes 100,000 Ugandan shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy more clothes to sell and also more cloth and textiles for making more new and original clothes.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale  and also to buy more cloth and textiles

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 32-year old married man from Lebanon. He has 3 young children. He has almost ten years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 2003 cultivating all types of vegetables and potatoes. He also uses plastic tents to grow his products. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work and seeds for the coming season. In the coming years, he hopes to continue the expansion of his business because his work is vital for his family.

loans.use: to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work and seeds for the coming season

loans.name: Sikyomu Widows' Association, Mpigi Group

texts.en:
30-year-old, enterprising N. Betty’s God-fearing and hardworking disposition has, for the last five years, been her reliable calling card in establishing a competitive niche in the market for her shoes and secondhand clothes business. Her business is located in Kyengera, Mpigi.

Betty is also a goodnatured widowed mother of four kids. She says it’s mostly the youth who are her customers. Her business started off small by her purchasing small bales of secondhand clothing that she sold at discount prices. This laid the foundation for her current business.

In a month, Betty makes 650,000 Ugandan shillings and with this loan she wants to buy more shoes to sell and also some secondhand clothing that she will sell as well.

Betty belongs to Sikyomu Widows' Association of Mpigi.

loans.use: To purchase more pairs of shoes and secondhand clothing to sell

loans.name: Sabra's Group

texts.en:
Sabra belongs to a small city in Pakistan called Chichawatni, which is famous for its agricultural industry. She is 38 years old and is the mother of four sons and a daughter. She lives in a three-room brick house with her family.

Sabra’s eldest son didn’t show any interest in studies and left school after the 6th standard. Now he operates a tea stall in the market and serves his customers by making delicious flavored tea. Her other children are receiving their education and are in different standards.

Sabra wants her children to complete their education and that’s why she works very hard. She sells bedsheets which she imports from the cities of Faisalabad and Lahore and sells them in Chichawatni.

Sabra came to Chichawatni after her marriage to M. A., who operates a sweetmeat (confectionary) business. He has a shop in the market from where he offers sweetmeats of different varieties to his clients. Sweetmeats are very popular and are widely used in weddings and on happy occasions.

Sabra has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to expand his sweetmeat business. With the loan, he will buy cooking oil, sugar, dried fruits and milk in large quantity. Sabra is hopeful that her husband will be able to improve his business with the help of this loan investment. This is her first loan application.

In the photo, Sabra is the lady who is holding a book (called her Asasah Passbook) in her hand.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy items for his business making and selling sweetmeats

loans.name: Peter Gathogo

texts.en:
Peter Gathogo is a businessman who has operated a retail shop in the heart of Nairobi’s city center for about ten years. He is 50 years old and is married to Eunice Wairimu who 46 years old. The wife is a farmer and she also contributes to the family’s total income. They have four children: their firstborn is 17 years old and their second-born is 13 years old and both are in secondary school; the other two children, age 10 years and 8 years, are in primary school.

Peter leant about KADET LTD through one of its credit officers and he is applying for his first loan of Kshs 50,000. He has no previous history with any other micro-finance institution and he plans to use the loan to purchase more stock for his retail shop and to venture into the distribution of Aberdare maize meal from Nyeri to Nairobi as a secondary business.

In the future, Peter hopes to have distribution stores for food products to supply hotels and schools within the city.

loans.use: To add more stock to his shop and to venture into the distribution of Aberdare maize meal

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The purchase of more cosmetics for resale and to improve her pig-husbandry business

loans.name: Lemmy

texts.en:
Lemmy L. is a businessman who lives in Kangemi in Nairobi city. He is 37 years old and married to Rachael, who is a housewife. They are blessed with two children. He is a carpenter and has been doing this business for six years with an income of 8,000 Kenyan shillings (Kshs.) per month. 

Lemmy learned about KADET LTD. through a friend and this is his first loan of Kshs.10,000 with KADET LTD. He plans to buy timber worth Kshs. 9,200, nails worth Kshs. 300 and paint worth Kshs. 500. His business is situated at a strategic place in Kagemi, where most of his clients live.

He wishes to grow his business to receive better income to sustain the family’s needs. He also plans to make use of the income that he will get to open up another workshop elsewhere so that he can move his family to a bigger house and take his children to a better school.

loans.use: To buy timber, nails and paint

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem is a resident of a small city called Chichawatni in Pakistan. She is a 42-year-old lady who sells clothes to earn money for her family. Her husband has a cigarette shop in the market where he sells different brands of cigarettes to his customers. 

Naseem is the mother of four sons and two daughters. All of them are getting an education. It is quite difficult for Naseem and her husband to afford their school fees which is why they work very hard. 

Her husband wants to buy different brands of cigarettes to sell from his shop in hopes of making more income, which is why Naseem has applied for a loan from Asasah for this purpose.  She is sure that her husband will be able to successfully upgrade his business by using his 15 years of experience in this business and make a positive use of this loan investment. 

This is the first time she has applied for a loan from any MFI. She hopes that it will bring positive change to her husband’s business and her family’s living standard will be improved. 

Note: In the picture, the lady who holds a book in her hand (called Asasah Passbook) in the first row, right corner is Naseem.

loans.use: To buy different brands of cigarettes for cigarette shop

loans.name: Amer

texts.ar: يعيش عامر البالغ من العمر 44 عاماً في منطقة بنت جبيل، هو وزوجته وأولاده الثلاث. يعمل عامر في مجال التبليط، فهو يقوم بعملية التبليط بالإضافة إلى جلي البلاط، ليظهر بأبهى حلة. يعمل عامر في هذه المهنة منذ 22 سنة، وهو دائماً يسعى إلى تطويرها. أنها المرة الثانية التي يتقدم فبها عامر بطلب قرض من المجموعة، وهو ذات تاريخ إقتراضي جيد. القرض السابق كان له تاثير إيجابي على تطور المصلحة، لذلك يعمد هذه المرة إلى شراء شاحنة نقل صغيرة (PICK UP) لتسهيل نقل عدته والبلاط من وإلى الورشة. زبائنه أي كان، جيرانه أقاربة و كذلك أصدقاء اصدقائة، وذلك لحرفيته في العمل، مما يجعل الزبائن يتوافدون إليه. يهدف عامر إلى التوسع في المستقبل، على أمل دخول عالم التعهدات العامة.
texts.en:
Amer, 44 years old, lives in Bint Jebeil with his wife and three children. Amer works in tiling: casting tiles and polishing them. Amer has been working in this field for 22 years and is always keen to develop his work. It is Amer's second loan from the Group and he has a good credit history. His first loan had a positive impact on the development of his work. This time, he seeks funding to buy a small pickup truck to facilitate the transfer of his tools and tiles to and from his workshop. His professionalism has helped him gain the trust of his clients, whether they be neighbors, relatives or friends of friends. Amer seeks to expand his business in the future, with the ultimate aim of entering the public contracting business.

Translated from Arabic by Rania ElMaraghy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a small pickup truck for his business

loans.name: Catheine Waithira

texts.en:
Catherine Waithira is a 36-year-old single lady who takes care of her three school-age children who are between 16 and four years. She runs a small kiosk in Ngara market, just next to the town centre in Nairobi. She has been in this business for three years. Most of her customers are business people who are mechanics in Ngara.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and is applying for her first loan of 21,000 KES. She plans to buy plastic chairs worth 10,000 KES, kitchenware worth 6,000 KES, and foodstuffs worth 5,000 KES.

Catherine hopes to grow her business with the income received, and has great hopes of operating a big hotel. She expects to have increased profit with a stable income which will improve her standard of living and offer her children a better education.

loans.use: To buy plastic chairs, kitchenware and foodstuffs

loans.name: Hatem

texts.ar: يعمل حاتم البالغ من العمر 41 عاماً في مجال السمانة، فهو يملك دكان سمانة صغير في منطقة بنت جبيل منذ عام 1994، يعتاش منه هو وزوجته وأولاده الثلاث.  يبيع حاتم في دكانه المواد الغذائية، المشروبات الغازية، المياه، والمعلبات، خضار وفاكهة، بالإضافة إلى الألعاب والهدايا. وبسبب الظروف الإقتصادية الصعبة في المنطقة، يعمل حاتم أيضاً في نقل الطلاب من وإلى المدارس خلال الموسم الدراسي. سمعته الطيبة في محيطه هي أساس تمكنه وتطوره في المنطقة، فهو يمتلك جميع الصفات الحسنة التي تدفع الأهل إلى الإسراع في تسجيل أولادهم معه. سبق وتعامل حاتم مع المجموعة، وكانت طريقة تسديده للقرض جيدة جداً، وهو الآن يتقدم بطلب قرض آخر لشراء سيارة للعمل عليها كمدخول إضافي، بالإضافة إلى تسديد الأقساط المدرسية المترتبة عليه، وشراء القرطاسية لمدرسة اولاده. إتقانه لعمله هو سر نجاحه.  يهدف حاتم إلى التوسع في المستقبل إن كان من إمتلاك شبكة نقل طلاب من وإلى المدارس، أو من خلال التوسع في مجال السمانة والمواد الغذائية بالجملة
texts.en:
Hatem, who is 41 years old, works as a grocer. Since 1994, he has owned a small grocery store in the area of Bint Jbeil. The store earns a living for him, his wife, and his three children. Hatem sells food products in his store, including soft drinks, water, canned products, vegetables and fruits, as well as toys and gifts. Due the region’s difficult economic conditions, Hatem also works as driver, transporting students and to and from their schools during the academic year. His good reputation in the area is the main reason behind his success, as he has all the qualities that motivate parents to use his services in transporting their children. Hatem had previously dealt with Al Majmoua, and was well able to repay his loan. He is now coming forward with a request for another loan to purchase a car that will help him earn additional income. The loan will also help him pay school expenses and purchase new school stationery for his children. His diligence is the secret to his success. Hatem aims to grow in the future by owning a transportation network that services students, or through expanding in the grocery and wholesale food products field.

Translated from Arabic by Ghaydaa Fahim, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a car for personal use and to expand his business.

loans.name: Katega Development Group, Mubende

texts.en:
Hard work and a social nature with a sense of determination has made B. Francis of Katega Development Group, Mubende, what he is today. This all began after taking a training course to become a professional tailor.  This has developed his future in the tailoring business which he operates from the Kanyogoga Trading Centre in Mubende. 

This seems to be fulfilling for him as he is in a position to earn 200,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. This has made the 38-year-old married father of four children able to care for his family's needs as he looks forward to achieving his dream of owning a big business in the area and buying himself more sewing machines.  With this loan he hopes to buy more stock of materials from which he can make good designs for the customers as he looks at future business expansion.

loans.use: For business expansion through buying more material and sewing machines

loans.name: Ainash

texts.en:
Ainash M. lives in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan. She is a widow and has three children: two grown daughters, who live on their own, and one son, who is the main light of Ainash’s life.  

She works in a local school in Naryn city and is characterized as a very well-wishing and positive person. As it was very hard to live on a low wage and to bring the children up by herself, Ainash decided to begin her own business in cattle breeding. In 2000, using her initial capital of 10,000 soms (KGS), she bought cattle for fattening and reselling. Because of an absence of appropriate conditions for livestock maintenance, Ainash decided to keep them in the neighboring village, at the farm of her mother-in-law. Such assistance from her late husband’s family serves as an example of the deeply rooted, warm relations between them and Ainash. 

In 2008,  Ainash applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS, which she used to buy more cattle. The revenues from this loan were used to pay for an education for Ainash’s son, who was eager to be a serviceman and successfully entered the military academy. 

Now Ainash intends to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden her business by purchasing 18 sheep and five bull-calves. In the future, using the revenues, she plans to construct her own barn near the house. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Francis Maina

texts.en:
Francis Maina is 32 years old, is married to Pauline Wambui, and has two children aged four years and two years old. He and his family live in Githurai.

Francis Maina sales tapes, CD’s and videos right in the town center along Mfangano Lane near the bus stage where most of his clients are passersby and those who have various commitments in town. He has been in this business for one-and-a-half years and earns a profit of Kshs 5,000.

Francis Maina learned about KADET LTD through one of its credit officers who enlightened him about the organization. Francis Maina is borrowing his first loan of Kshs 20,000 with which he intends to use half to add more stock of tapes, CD’s and videos and use the other half to pay rent.

In the future, Francis Maina desires to own a music shop that will create him the opportunity to achieve financial stability and hence improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To add more stock of tapes, CD's and videos and to pay his rent

loans.name: Khadra

texts.en:
Khadra is a talented tailor. She started this project in her house two years ago with basic tools, tailoring for the neighbors. Now Khadra is well known and customers come to her from different places. Khadra has one son named Arkan, who is 28 years old and a Palestinian NationA. Authority employee. 

Khadra came to FATEN and received a $1000 loan to purchase a tailoring machine to help her enhance her work and finish it faster. Khadra would like to develop her small workshop into a bigger one and start employing other women who need a job in the city.

Khadra appears in the picture above, working.

loans.use: To purchase a tailoring machine

loans.name: Willikistar

texts.en:
Forty-eight-year-old Willikistar is a single mother with six school-aged children, all of whom attend school.

Willikistar is a farmer in the town of Kitale in western Kenya. She has been farming for eight years and employs one farmhand. She sells her vegetables, maize, beans and tomatoes to the local market. She also earns income from her motorbike business.

Willikistar fully repaid her second loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 30,000 KES to expand her poultry business. She says that the income from this loan will improve the livelihood of her family and she will be able to provide her family with eggs and meat for consumption.

Willikistar hopes that, in the next 5 years, she will have set up her own posho mill (a grinding machine that crushes maize into maize flour).

loans.use: To expand her poultry business

loans.name: Gufronboy

texts.en: N. Gufronboy has been dedicated to the business of cattle ranching for the last six years. This business requires a lot of dedication due to the fact that it demands a lot of effort to carry out the breeding. This is also true since it requires the strict control of every one of the animals and, at the same time, the feed and care of those that are older. It is necessary to emphasize that, through this business, Gufronboy is able to maintain his spouse and his three children. It is because of this that he is soliciting a loan through IMON International. The loan will allow him to be buy more animals, which he will raise and sell in the market. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more calves to raise and sell

loans.name: Twisakilala Group, Jinja

texts.en:
B. Mwajab of Twisakilala Group, Jinja, is 38 years old and has, for the last four years, been in charge of a business selling secondhand clothes in Wakitaka, Jinja. With profits from this business she has, to a certain degree, managed to elevate her family’s welfare.

What has been of paramount importance to Mwajab all these years has been hard work. Her amiable personality has also played so much into her favor as this has gotten her many friends who in turn have turned into clients.

Prior to this, Mwajab was selling timber which she still does, albeit on a small scale. This was her first business but, because she was not making ends meet, she decided to try bearing a hand in her current business undertaking. She has never looked back since, as this business has proved to be worthwhile.

In a week Mwajab makes profits that add up to 180,000 Ugandan shillings. With this loan she wants to buy more bales of secondhand clothing and also new clothes, especially for Christmas sales.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of  secondhand clothes and also new clothing

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.en: O. Marhabo is 30 years old and is married with two children of school age. Marhabo runs a café where she cooks national meals and the business has generated a stable income during the last six years. At the same time, together with her husband, Marhabo runs a cattle-breeding business. Now, Marhabo is planning to purchase more foodstuffs for her café and more cattle. With this purpose in mind, she requests 4,000 Somoni. She thanks all those supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for her café and more cattle to raise and sell

loans.name: Zainurakhon

texts.en: Zainurakhon M. is 53 years old. She is a widow with three children. Zainurakhon is a market vendor. She sells dishes and plates of an oriental style in the central local market. Zainurakhon has been in this business for 17 years. During these years, the business turned into a successful one, allowing Zainurakhon to support her family. Her business generates the main income for her family. Now Zainurakhon is planning to increase the stock and to purchase the dishes and plates wholesale. For this purpose, she requests 7,000 Somoni. Zainurakhon thanks everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan timely. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing dishes and plates wholesale in order to increase the range of goods for selling

loans.name: Ndere Bakyara Tukole, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
K. Jovia has really improved her standard of living by starting a grocery and produce store. A member of the Ndere Bakyara Tukole group, she is 53 years old. After 18 years in the farming industry, K. changed her business to sell products like beans, millet, sorghum, maize, and fruits. She sells these from Rwoya trading center in Rukungiri, where she earns 150,000 UGX on a monthly basis. 

A married mother of eight chidlren, Jovia has been working hard, as she knows she has responsibilities to her family, including paying school fees and other necessities. She pays for her family's expenses with help from her husband. One challenge in her business is having a small supply of inventory. This loan will enable her to expand the business by buying more products to increase her ability to sell to customers when they are ready to buy. Having more stock on hand will enable her to earn more sales revenue and, therefore, improve her quality of life. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and build a store.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Azimjon

texts.en:
S. Azimjon works in agriculture. For this, he leaves his home to head for his distant farmlands that he must care for and fertilize at certain times. He has been farming for the past 20 years. Azimjon learned all the secrets and experiences of farming from his father. He tells us that, beyond the hard work he does for the good of his family, he is asking for a loan to purchase potatoes to save and sell when the price for them increases. With the part of the loan, he will also buy cattle.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase potatoes and cattle

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where she has been farming for six years. Her mixed farm produces eggs, vegetables, fruits and maize, which she sells to the local market. She also operates a phone business in the same area.

Christine is 41 years old. She is married with two children who are 17 and 19. Both children attend school. She has been pictured with her cow since it was not possible to get a photo of her in her poultry farm.

She has requested this loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her poultry farming. This loan will enable her to increase her stock of poultry and consequently increase her income. She says that this income will improve her life and that of her family and she will be able to expand her business and provide for her family. In the future, she wishes to have 2,000 chickens and be the main supplier of eggs at the local market.

loans.use: To expand her poultry farm

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
N. Alice lives in the Kyebando neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is widowed and has four children, all of whom are in school.  Alice has a business of selling matooke (green bananas). She used to sell all kinds of food but now she is selling green bananas. She has been in this business for less than a year (a few months), and she works 7 days out of every week. Alice sells her products at the market at retail.  Alice has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of matooke (green bananas).   She also generates additional income through leasing property to tenants.

The main business challenge for Alice is transportation costs.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to construct a permanent building for her business.  Alice lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include paying for water, electricity, and food.

loans.use: To buy more matooke (green bananas) to sell

loans.name: Zuhro

texts.en: K. Zuhro has a small shoe-sales business located at Ganjina market in Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan. She is married and has three children. Zuhro has been in business for thirteen years and has worked hard over the years to develop a successful business and to help meet the needs of her family. She currently sells a selection of men’s shoes. She has requested a loan of 1,500 USD to help purchase more inventory. Zuhro enjoys being self-employed and would like to continue growing and developing her business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Nancy Wamweru

texts.en:
Nancy Wamweru is a hardworking lady who runs a greengrocery stall in Huruma, Nairobi. She is a 44-year-old single mother who takes care of her four children: aged 24 years in college; Michael, 20 years old, and Peter, 18 years old, in secondary school.

Nancy has operated her business for ten years and earns an income of Kshs 12,000 per month; most of her clients are her neighbors in Huruma and passersby.

Nancy was introduced to KADET by a client who is already a member and she is applying for her first loan of Kshs 20,000. She intends to use the loan to add more stock to her greengrocery and to add to her business by selling french fries (locally known as chips) and fruit salads as a secondary business.
	
Nancy desires to see herself own a hotel (restaurant) and be able to supply fruits and vegetables to the hotel owners in the near future. She wishes to offer her children the best education.

loans.use: To add more stock to her greengrocery and to diversify into selling french fries and fruit salads

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in a city called Gujranwala which is one-and-a-half hours away from the city of Lahore, Pakistan. Gujranwala city is well known as an industrial city.

Razia is 42 years old and is married to M. S. who is a loader by trade: he loads vegetables and delivers them from one place to another using a vehicle called a Hyundai Shahzore (a small truck). Razia supports her family by doing sewing work for her neighborhood clients.

Razia is the mother of three daughters. 17-year-old Saba is in 10th standard and 10-year-old Ayesha is studying in 3rd standard. Razia’s eldest daughter, Sonya, runs a beauty salon from her home. She is 21 years old and left school after completing 10th standard.

Razia has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan, he will repair his vehicle and be able to continue his business in an efficient way.

Razia is a regular loan user of Asasah and is on her 3rd loan. In her previous loans she has proved herself a responsible client who never missed a single meeting and paid her installments on time.

loans.use: To repair her husband's vehicle that he uses in his business

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya runs a small business selling women's clothing at the central market in Kherson. She has been in this business for four years. During this time, she has learned that there is a large and constant demand for the items she sells. She also learned that, to be successful in sales, one needs to have a large variety and good client service. She feels this is something she can do well.

Natalya, her husband Andrei, and their 12-year-old son, Daniel, live in a small apartment. Both her son and her husband support her in her business.

Natalya would like to borrow 13,700 Grivnas to increase her assortment of the goods that she sells. She hopes to make additional profit and spend it on current family needs.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of her merchandise

loans.name: Saad

texts.ar: سعد شاب أعزب، يبلغ من العمر 24 عاماً، يعمل سائق حافلة ركاب سياحية (فان)  منذ 2005. وهو أعزب يسكن في منطفة شتورة. هذه هي المرة الأولى التي يطلب فيها سعد قرض من المجموعة، وذلك لكي يشتري حافلة نقل صغيرة (فان) لتقوية المصلحة. حبه لعمله هو سر نجاحه، قلة رأس المال كانت من أبرز الصعوبات التي واجهته في بداية الطريق.  زبائنه هم اصدقائه، جيرانه، أقربائه وسياح أجانب و لبنانيين. يسعى سعد إلى إنشاء شركته الخاصه للنقل السياحي في المستقبل.
texts.en:
Saad is a 24-year-old, single man who lives in Chtaura. He has worked as a driver of a tourist mini-van service since 2005. This is Saad’s first loan request from Al Majmoua. Saad will use this loan to purchase a mini-van that will help him expand his activities. His love for his job is the secret to his success. Initially, one of the biggest challenges facing Saad is the lack of capital. Saad’s clients are his friends, neighbors, relatives, as well as Lebanese and foreign tourists. In the future, Saad aspires to set up a private tourist transport business.

Translated from Arabic by Ghaydaa Fahim, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a minivan

loans.name: Salah

texts.en:
Salah M. is a National Palestinian Authority employee, married and a father who takes care of his family and parents. Salah's dad owned a workshop where he produced Aluminium home accessories such as windows, doors, cupboard... etc. Salah's salary barely covers basic needs, therefor he decided to start working with his father.

Saleh gained a good experience working with his dad and started developing the 10-years old workshop, in this attempt he took a $2,000 loan to buy an aluminum piston and other tools needed to enhance work quality and answer the customers orders.
Since Salah started working with his dad and his financial situation is improving .

loans.use: Purchase an aluminum piston

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
N. Edith lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has six children, all of whom are in school. She lives in a home that she rents and which has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and feeding the family.

Edith has a business running a retail shop. She has been in this business for over ten years and she works seven days a week. She sells her products retail in a shop and her main business challenge is seasonality.

Edith has requested a loan of 1,200,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerrycans of cooking oil.

Edith’s goals and aspirations for her business are to make profits to improve on her standard of living, and to own a wholesale shop. She would also like to build her own house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerrycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Manzura

texts.en:
M. Manzura is 29 years old and she is a very good entrepreneur. She is married and the loving mother of two children. Her husband has no fixed job and this is the reason that two years ago she decided to start her own business. Manzura started with very little merchandise, but little by little her business grew and she started to sell clothes with excellent results. She is very clear about the secret of success in a business. She knows it is the variety of products that she offers because if a client is looking for something that she does not have, he or she may never return to her. For this reason, she tries to be fully stocked. Manzura is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase merchandise and new clothes for the season.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.ar: محمد شاب أعزب من منطقة بنت جبيل، يبلغ من العمر 33 عاماً. يملك محمد مكتبة لبيع الكتب المدرسية، القرطاسية، الحقائب المدرسية والتصوير، منذ العام 2005. سبق لمحمد وتعامل مع المجموعة وهو مقترض حسن السمعة والسلوك. يتقدم محمد الآن بطلب قرض من المجموعة بهدف تقوية المصلحة للعام الدراسي الحالي. في البدء كان رأس المال لديه ضعيف تمت تقويته من خلال القرض السابق الذي إستحصل عليه من المجموعة. أما الآن فالعمل يتطور تدريحياً. معاملته الجيدة للزبائن وأسعاره المجدروسة في ظل الاوضاع الإقتصادية الصعبة، هي التي تمييزه وتمييز عمله عن سائر المكنبات الأخرى في الجوار. يأمل محمد إفتتاح فرع آخر لمكتبته في منطقة أخرى، على أن يستمر هذا التطور والإمتداد ليشمل مناطق مختلفة.
texts.en:
Mohamad is a 33-year-old, single man from Bint Jbeil. Since 2005 he has owned a bookstore, in which he sells school books, stationery, school bags and photography. Mohamad previously dealt with A.-Majmoua and enjoys a good reputation. He is now asking for a loan to boost his business as the new academic year approaches. In the beginning he lacked capitA. and he improved it with the previous loan he obtained from the group. The business is now developing gradually. His good manner with customers and his reasonable prices at a time of economic difficulties distinguish him and his business from other bookshops in the neighborhood. Mohamad hopes to one day open another branch in another area and to keep developing his business to include different areas.

Translated from Arabic by Rebecca Saab Saade, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy the necessary products for the coming school year

loans.name: Bashiran's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran lives in a city called Gujranwala, which is a big industrial city in Pakistan. She is a mother of 3 sons and 2 daughters. Both of her elder sons work in the factory and earn a small income. Her elder daughter does sewing work at her home. Her younger children are getting their education by attending school. Bashiran does business in order to financially support her family. She sells clothes in her native city. Her husband's name is M. R.. He is a loader by trade and loads different items such as construction supplies and fruits & vegetables. He put loads on his donkey cart and delivers them from one place to another. They have been living in a two-room little house made of bricks for the last 15 years.  

Bashiran has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy a new donkey cart because the old cart has become rough and rotten in different areas. Due to its roughness Bashiran’s husband can’t put heavy loads on it and, as a result, his business is affected. Bashiran is hopeful that by purchasing a new donkey cart, her husband will be able to do his work more comfortably and make more income.
She is a regular user of Asasah and has a good credit record. This is her fourth loan application.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart for loading business

loans.name: Mugoma Feed Family Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en: There is a fascinating story behind the determined Rwamwenge John of Mugoma Feed Family group, Kyenjojo, who is not afraid of diversity in business. This hard-working married father of seven children ventured into the agro produce and grocery business four years ago, dealing in general food crops like bananas, beans, maize flour, ground nuts, peas and many others at Mugoma trading Centre, Kyenjojo. Due to the pressing need to educate his children, he began this business with his personal savings and food supplies from his garden to supplement the family income. With this loan, John will be able to purchase more stock and be able to improve his earnings as he looks forward to living a self-sustaining life through educating his children and improving his household income.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his business

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima Ghulam Murtaza's Group

texts.en:
G. fatima G. M. is a widow who lost her husband a few years ago when he died unexpectedly. She is the mother of two sons, both of whom work. They left school after completing their 10th standard and started to work in order to supplement the family’s income. G. fatima’s elder son works in the government sector while her younger son is a tailor by profession. The family lives in Gujrawala, Pakistan, which is one of Pakistan’s main industrial cities.

After her husband’s death G. fatima started a PCO (a public phone facility where people pay for their calls by the minute) in her home for the people in her neighborhood. She uses one of her rooms for this purpose. She has been in business for the last seven years and has successfully developed trust in her business by providing her customers with good quality services. She is a client who is very aware of her responsibilities.

G. fatima has applied for a loan, her second from Asasah, for her PCO business. With the loan she will buy calling cards and a telephone set to provide better calling services for her customers. She is hopeful that her income will definitely increase after making such an investment.

loans.use: To buy a phone set and calling cards for her PCO

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
For the past seven years Stephen M. has been running a farm in Kanyegaramire, Kyenjojo, where he grows bananas, maize and beans. With good management and customer relations, his farm has been generating a good profit of 140,000 UGX on a monthly basis. With hard work Stephen looks forward to improving his banana plantation through mulching and applying pesticides to combat insects and disease that are reducing his returns currently.

A loan will definitely give his farm a new lease on life for some time as he looks to expanding and growing pineapples. This loan will allow him to purchase pesticides and mulches and so get better yields. His motive is to earn more money to pay for his children’s fees and expand his business for more income.

loans.use: To buy mulches and pesticides

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara is widowed and has a son. She runs a small business selling women's clothing at an open-air market in Kherson, Ukraine. She has been in business for fifteen years. Her monthly income is 2,500 UAH.

A large variety of clothes, a good location and great client service have helped Tamara to succeed in her business. She has many repeat clients who buy clothing from her. Tamara uses her income to help her son financially during difficult economic times.

Tamara is requesting a loan of 8,750 UAH to purchase seasonal inventory. She hopes to receive additional income and use it for her and her son's current needs.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal inventory

loans.name: Adel

texts.ar: عادل شاب متزوج طموح، يعيش في منطقة صور مع زوجته وأولاده الثلاثة. يمل عادل سيارة فان يستخدمها في مصلحته التي يزاولها منذ العام 2000، وهي بيع القهوة، الشاي، النسكافة و الأراكيل المتجول بين قرى صور. يعمد عادل في أغلب الأوقات إلى إتخاذ مقر ثابت له يقصده فيه زبائنه المعتادون. نوعية منتجاته والنظافة في مهنته يشجع الكثير من الأشخاص، منهم الاصدقاء، الجيران وبعض السياح إلى شراء ما ينتج. سبق لعادل التعامل مع المجموعة، وهو ذات تاريخ إقتراضي جيد، وكان للقرض تاثير إيجابي على حياته، فقد حسن وضعه المادي جداً. في هذه المرة ينوي عادل إفتتاح محل لبيع الأجهزة الخليوية، بالإضافة إلى الصيانة. وذلك لزيادة مدخوله، وتحسين الوضع المادي والإجتماعي لأولاده وعائلته بالدرجة الأولى. يهدف عادل إلى توسيع نطاق عمله في المستقبل ليشمل مقهى صغير يجمع فيه زبائنه.
texts.en:
Adel is married and lives in Tyre with his wife and 3 children. He is ambitious, and is tired of his van, which he uses for the work he’s been doing since 2000; selling coffee, tea, and hookahs as a peddler, roaming from one village to the other in Tyre. Adel often settles in one location where his regular customers hang out. The quality of his product and his hygiene standards encourage many people, including friends, neighbors, and tourists, to buy his products. Adel has previously dealt with Al-Majmoua and has a good borrowing history. His previous loan had a positive impact on his life, as it significantly improved his financial situation. This time, Adel is planning to open a shop to sell and repair mobile phones, thus increasing his income and first and foremost improving the financial and social situation for his children and family. Adel aims to expand his business in the future to include a small café in which his customers can gather.

Translated from Arabic by Rebecca Saab Saade, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To open a mobile phone shop

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
N. Jane lives in the Nalukolongo neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has six children, all of whom are in school. Jane runs a business  of selling bark cloth. She has been in this business for nine years, and works six days a week. Jane sells her products at the market, by means of retail. She has requested for a loan of 500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more supplies of bark cloth for her business.     
Jane's main business challenge is thieves. Her goal and aspiration for her business is to start going to villages for bark cloth. She decided to join MCDT SACCO because she wanted additional capital. Jane lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include paying utility bills and rent for her business.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for her bark cloth business

loans.name: Butunduzi Abagambakamu Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
In this world, one needs a pinch of extra effort and hard work to earn a living, especially in this era of stiff competition. To maximize on this point, Francis M. of the Butunduzi Abagambakamu Group, Kyenjojo, who is 40 years and studied carpentry, has been running a carpentry workshop for close to three years. 

He makes windows, chairs, tables, doors and many more products for customers. This business is located in Butunduzi, Kyenjojo district. He has this enterprise alongside his farming practices, which earn him an additional income. He is therefore seeking this loan to help him purchase materials, including timber, nails, cover cloth and leather cover materials for chairs. This will help him to improve the quality of his products and get him more customers, thus more revenue.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials like timber

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. lives in the Nalukolongo neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. A widowed mother of eight children, one of whom is in school, Margaret has been operating a chicken-selling business for two years, working six days each week. Margaret, who sells her products from home, is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more chicken. She also generates additional income through selling water and owning rental housing.

The main business challenges for Margaret are defaulters and the transportation of chickens from the villages to her stall in Nalukolongo. Her goals for her business include expanding further, increasing sales, and starting to rear chickens. Margaret lives in a home that she owns and has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more chicken  for resale

loans.name: God

texts.en:
God A. has multiple businesses. He has a bar, is involved in brewing, the distillation of gin, the buying and selling of produce, and the production and selling of bricks. He employs his two nephews, and most of his customers are area residents.

To start his businesses, God first sold some of his cattle and produce from his farm; then two years ago he went into the brick-laying business in his home area of Ikoba-Myeri, Kyenjojo. Due to the popularity of bricks as building materials, there has been a consistently high demand for his stock.

From all his businesses, this married father of two children earns 450,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. With this loan, he will be able to purchase more crates of sodas and beer to meet customer demand, which will improve his sales and help him to expand the business.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and sodas for business expansion.

loans.name: Paul  Njenga

texts.en:
Paul, a 23-year-old single gentleman, sells children's and ladies' clothes by hawking in the Nairobi Central Business District (N.C.B.D). He lives in Kangemi and has been in this business for four years, with a monthly income of Kshs.4,000.

Paul came to learn about KADET LTD through the Credit officer, and he is now applying for his first loan of Kshs.10,000 to buy more clothes to sell and to rent a stall which will give his customers easy access to his goods. He hopes to grow his business with the profit generated and later hopes to own a boutique and distribute school uniforms.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and  rent a stall

loans.name: Bridgit

texts.en:
Bridgit is 33 years old and married with four children who are now between the ages of 3½ and 13. Three of her children attend school. She has a mixed farm in Kitale town, western Kenya, where she has been farming for ten years. She employs one person from her community. She also earns income from charcoal sales and fish mongering.

Bridgit has requested this loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The income from this loan will go towards the education of her children, and the milk will help improve their health. She faces the challenges of the fluctuation in prices of products and the lack of a reliable market. Despite the challenges, she hopes to establish a veterinary shop and acquire two more dairy cows in the future.

She urges Juhudi to keep up the good work lifting up farmers' lives.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase cash crops like coffee, maize and cassava and more retail items like bags of sugar

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie N. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married  and has  two children, both of whom are in school.    Marjorie has a business of selling various eatables like samosas, chapati  , donuts. She has been in this business for three years and she works six days out of every week. 

Marjorie sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. Marjorie has requested for a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerrycans of cooking oil, wheat flour  and also a glass display to show case her goods. She also generates additional income through working as a teacher.

The main business challenges for Marjorie include transportation costs and the ever-increasing prices of cooking oil and wheat flour. Her goals and aspirations for her business are expanding it and putting in a new display case, and also to own a fully stocked bakery.   

Marjorie lives in a home that she owns. She doesn't have access to electricity but  has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food and medicine.

loans.use: Buying more jerrycans of cooking oil and wheat flour and a glass case to display her things

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela L. is 40 years old. She is married with five children who are between the ages of nine and twenty. Four of the children are currently attending school. Pamela has been farming for the last twenty years in Kitale town, western Kenya. Her mixed farm produces maize, beans, bananas and milk which she sells locally. She also earns income from her salon in the same location.

Pamela recently repaid a previous loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 61,200 KES to start a poultry project and purchase and insure a dairy cow. The income from this loan will help improve the livelihood of the family in terms of education and health. Her primary challenges are poor prices for her products and the lack of a proper market. However, she hopes to acquire five more dairy cows and maintain a poultry farm in the future.

Pamela comments that Juhudi should diversify their products to provide school fees loans as well.

loans.use: To start a poultry project and purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a member of Elshadai group in Faulu Kenya.   She sells clothes to earn a living. She also runs a cafeteria and a retail shop in Muthurwa open-air market.  She appreciates Faulu Kenya because her business and her life have improved.  She has requested 40,000 KES to buy second-hand clothes, sugar and cooking flour for use in her cafeteria.  She sees herself owning a big supply shop for clothes.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes, sugar and cooking flour

loans.name: Celestine  Akisol

texts.en:
Celestine Akisol O. is a thirty-seven-year-old single mother of four children aged twelve, ten, six and four years. All of her children go to school, and she has been able to pay for school fees and bring up the children using the profits she gets from her busy beauty salon.

Celestine learned about KADET from a friend who is a KADET client, and she plans to use this first loan to buy additional products like hair treatment kits, oil and weaves for use in the salon. Her plan is to own and develop a plot of land, thus improving her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her salon

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon A. is a married woman who lives in Purok Peacock, Brgy. Cubay Masville, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  a coffee shop, a general store and a food vending business. Her husband, Mamerto A. Sr., who is 50 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have six children who are 17 to 28 years old. 

Corazon joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Corazon has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 18,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 9000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing 18,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more foodstuffs to sell in her coffee shop and her general store to sustain her businesses and continue to save for future home repairs and expansion of her business. Corazon A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. is married and has five children, two of whom are in school. She lives in the Kyebando neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. Rose lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food and utility bills.

Rose owns a bar; previously she was dealing in secondhand clothes. She has been in this business for three years, and she works seven days a week. She also generates additional income by renting rooms to tenants. The main business challenges for Rose include transportation expenses and defaulters.

Rose has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer, soda and jerry cans of local drinks. Her goals are to expand the bar by constructing another building and own a fully-stocked bar.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer, soda and jerry cans of local drinks

loans.name: Tongi

texts.en:
Tongi is a water vendor in Kayaba village, a slum in the Jogoo Road area. He also owns rental houses in the village so as to supplement his income. The slum setting favors his business.  

He has engaged in the business for eight years. Faulu Kenya has taught him how to be tolerant to customers and budget well for his business. He has requested 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy water pumps and water pipes.  He sees himself becoming successful in five years.

loans.use: To buy water pumps and water pipes

loans.name: Aracili

texts.en:
Aracili L. is a married woman who lives in Bangkal Highway, Brgy. Jonobjonob, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and a computer-gaming business. Her husband Antonio L., who is 60 years old, also helps with his wife's business activities. They have 4 children who range in age from 21 to 33 years old. Two of her children have their own families. 

Aracili joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Aracili has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.
