Her previous loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 22,000, which she intends to use as revolving capital for her general store so that she can earn enough to continue to save up for the future to improve their house and for their basic needs. Aracili L. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

<b>About NWTF: <b>

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a hardworking and visionary man. He operates the Pabeto Video and Photography Services shop to earn a living. His business is located in an urban setting near one of the biggest hotels in Nairobi city center. He has been running his business with only one employee and he hopes to employ more people in the future.  

He has benefited from Faulu Kenya because he has learned about a good business foundation and customer-care skills. He wants to purchase a video camera with the loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings.

loans.use: To purchase a video camera

loans.name: Suzette

texts.en:
Suzette M. is a 46-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures:  selling Ready-to-Wear (RTW) clothes, raising livestock and food vending. She lives in Purok 6, Brgy. Cubay, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her RTW sales, livestock and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 7,200 PHP. Suzette is now borrowing 15,000 PHP to sustain and grow her businesses. This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Suzette aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.


About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at Kiva.org.

loans.use: Working capital for her business ventures

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline is 38 years old and married with three children. For a living, she runs a retail shop where she sells foodstuffs.  Her business is located in the slums.  Therefore, most of her customers are low income earners.  She has been running the business for five years.  She hopes to own permanent rental houses in the future.  She has been an active member of Faulu Kenya and has previously had four loans.  She has requested a loan of 80,000 KES to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married lady with two children. She was previously employed before she went into business. Currently, she is operating a mobile money-transfer business. She also offers printing and typing services. Besides this, she is a dairy farmer.  

Mary has been handling the two businesses for one year and most of her customers are people from her local community. Mary hopes to open about 10 other outlets for the mobile money-transfer business. She has requested a 60,000 Kenyan shillings loans to increase float in her mobile money-transfer business.

loans.use: To increase float in her mobile money transfer business

loans.name: Arlen

texts.en:
Arlen C. is a 36-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  seaweed (guso) farming and food vending. She lives in Pulo, Brgy Cervantes, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She cultures Eucheuma seaweed (guso) along the coast line and sells it as raw material for carrageenan, a very in-demand binder used in food products. Because seaweed farming does not involve constant work, Arlen can earn additional income by selling cooked food, doubling her earning capacity.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1996 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her seaweed (guso) farming and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 15,000. 

Arlen is now borrowing PHP 19,000 to purchase seaweed materials and use as additional capital for food vending.  This will be her 8eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Arlen aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at Kiva.org.

loans.use: Additional capital to sustain her seaweed business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en: Anecita F. is a 44 year old married woman who supports her family through her bakery specializing in cookies. She lives in Barangay Poblacion, Oslob, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her bakery business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Anecita is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can buy the ingredients for her cookie production. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Anecita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Silvia Liliana

texts.es:
Silvia D. 31 años D. edad, es casada vive junto a su esposo en San Miguel, aun no tienen hijos y ella se dedica al comercio D. cosméticos desD. hace 5 años, ella estudia en la universidad y aprovecha para ofrecer su mercadería entre sus compañeras D. clases. Silvia necesita D. un préstamo para fortalecer su negocio y brindar mayor diversidad D. productos D. belleza, ella invertirá en la compra D. labiales, cremas, bases y otros productos que le son demandados por sus clientes.
Este préstamo ayudara a que Silvia mejore sus ingresos aumentando las ventas y obteniendo mayor estabilidad con su negocio.
El Sueño D. Silvia es mejorar las condiciones del negocio, finalizar sus estudios y tener una vida mejor.
texts.en:
Silvia is 31 years old and married. She lives with her husband in San Miguel. They do not yet have children. She has been selling cosmetics for five years. She is a university student, and she takes the opportunity to sell her merchandise to her classmates. Silvia needs a loan to strengthen her business and offer a greater diversity of beauty products. She will buy lipsticks, creams, foundations, and other products that are in demand by her customers. The loan will help Silvia improve her income by increasing sales. Then she will obtain greater stability in her business. Silvia’s dream is to improve conditions in her business, finish her education, and to have a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cosmetics

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is a 34 year old business lady who runs a chemists (pharmacy) with two employees.  She is married with a ten-year-old child.  She left her previous job where she was working as a school nurse and started her business in 2007.

In her pharmacy, she also sells mobile phone airtime cards and beauty products. She has managed to learn about customer care and good business foundation through Faulu Kenya. She hopes to move her business into the town centre in the future.

She has requested 50,000 KES to buy mobile phone airtime cards, more chemists products such as medicine and disinfectants and beauty products.  She describes herself as a hardworking and visionary lady

loans.use: To buy mobile phone airtime cards, more chemist products such as medicine and disinfectants and beauty products

loans.name: Zulma Carolina

texts.es:
Zulma vive en San Miguel junto a su hija de 8 años de edad y su madre, Ella trabaja como cocinera desde hace 4 años para ayudar a su hija con sus gastos y los de su madre, por su experiencia ella no siente dificultad en ejercer este oficio. 
Zulma solicita un préstamo que invertira en los estudios de su hija comprandole todos los utiles necesarios, dicho credito ayudara a que su hija siga adelante con su educacion con mejores condiciones.
El sueño de ella es ver que su hija crezca con la educacion necesaria y en un futuro sea una buena profesional y que mejore su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Zulma lives in San Miguel with her eight year old daughter and her mother. For four years she has been working as a cook to help with her daughter’s and her mother’s expenses. Thanks to her experience, she does not find working in this field to be difficult. Zulma is requesting a loan for her daughter’s education. She will buy her all of the necessary supplies. The loan will help her daughter get ahead in her education under better conditions. Her dream is to see her daughter grow with the necessary education and to become a good professional in the future. She also dreams of improving her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Her daughter's education

loans.name: Jose Misael

texts.es:
Don José es un señor de 50 años de edad, está casado y vive junto a una hija en El Transito de San Miguel, tiene un negocio en el mercado municipal donde ofrece verduras y granos básicos, este negocio fue iniciativa de don José desde hace 10 años y lo atiende desde las cinco de la mañana hasta las tres de la tarde todos los días de la semana; Él está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de arroz, frijol,  aceite, azúcar y verduras que son los productos que mas demanda tienen en  el mercado.
Este préstamo ayudara a que crezca el negocio y pueda ofrecer lo necesario a sus clientes así poder mantenerles satisfechos y que siempre prefieran consumir de su negocio dándole a don José los ingresos necesarios para cubrir las necesidades de su hogar.
Los sueños de José es ver crecer su negocio para ayudar a su hija y que termine los estudios para en un futuro pueda ser una profesional.
texts.en:
José is a married, 50 year old man. He lives with his daughter in El Transito in San Miguel. He has a business in the municipal market where he sells vegetables and basic grains. José started this business ten years ago. He tends his business from five in the morning until three in the afternoon every day of the week. He is requesting a loan to buy rice, beans, oil, sugar, and vegetables. These are the products that have the most demand in the market. This loan will help his business grow, and he will be able to offer his customers what they need. That way he will be able to keep them satisfied and always preferring to buy from his business. This will give José the needed income to cover the household necessities. José’s dreams are to see his business grow so that he can help his daughter finish her education. Then she will be able to become a professional in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, beans, oil, and vegetables

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria C. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Calumpang, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a food vending business.  Her husband Esteban C., who is 60 years old, works as a chief mate to earn his living.  They have no children who are 18 to 36 years old.

Gloria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gloria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her 7th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 which she intends to use to purchase raw materials so that she could continue to save up for the future and to provide for the needs of her family. Gloria C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.


 About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.
 
Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.
__________________________________

loans.use: purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Carlos Antonio

texts.es:
Carlos se dedica a la venta de sorbetes y paletas, vive con su esposa y tienen una hija de 10 años de edad, residen en San Miguel, Él se dedica a este tipo de negocio desde hace mucho tiempo y fue por iniciativa propia, su trabajo es abastecer tiendas que están fuera de la ciudad y en pueblos de la zona. Don Carlos está solicitando un préstamo que necesita para comprar los productos al contado por que de esta forma lo encuentra mas cómodos, el quiere invertir en paletas, sorbetes y así abastecer a mas tiendas y conseguir más clientes.
Este crédito le ayudara a crecer con el negocio, a ofrecer más productos que le generen los ingresos necesarios para cubrir las necesidades básicas del hogar.
El sueño de don Carlos es tener un negocio rentable que ayude a solventar sus gastos y ofrecer una mejor vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Carlos sells sorbets and popsicles. He lives with his wife and 10 year old daughter in San Miguel. Carlos has been this type of business for a long time and started as a result of his own initiative. His work involves supplying stores located outside of the city and in towns across the district. Don Carlos is requesting a loan because he needs to buy his goods with cash since it is easier that way. He plans to invest in popsicles and sorbets so that he can supply more shops and obtain more customers.

This loan will help him grow his business by offering more products that generate the income needed to cover his basic household necessities. Don Carlos dreams of having a profitable business to help meet his expenses and provide a better life for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sorbets & popsicles

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has four children, all of whom are in school. Sylvia has a business of a restaurant. She has been in this business for five years and she works six days out of every week. Sylvia works in the Kisaasi market and sells on a retail basis. 

Sylvia has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sacks of charcoal and foodstuffs like bunches of bananas, beef and rice. She also generates additional income through selling charcoal. The main business challenges for Sylvia include seasonality and defaulters.  

Her goal for her business is to own a hotel. She decided to join MCDT because she wanted additional capital. 

Sylvia lives in a home that she rents. She doesn't have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal, bunches of bananas and a bag of rice

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en: Leonora A. is a widow who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Cabagna-an, La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and farming. Leonora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Leonora has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 11,000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th loan, she is borrowing 20,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more stock to sell in her general store so that she can continue to earn and save up for the future education of her child and the future needs of her family. Leonora A. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Bakole Wakiso Development Grouo - Lugazi Group

texts.en:
Fatuma N. belongs to the Bakole Wakiso Development Group-Lugazi. She is 40 years old and happily married with two kids, both of whom are attending school in Namengo-Lugazi. 

To get a viable and sustainable financial means of subsistence that she and her family could rely on, she began her fish selling business two years ago. To take root in this business, she had to use savings from her bar business, which is still a side business for her. In a week, out of her fish business, she makes profits totaling up to 500,000 shillings.  

Under the auspices of this loan, Fatuma wants to boost her business by buying more fish to resell and some to smoke and keep as reserve just in case client demand goes up. Just like in any other part of Uganda, fish customers in Lugazi normally have preferences, some an inclination for smoked fish and some fancy fresh fish. The upshot of increased sales, Fatuma gleefully says, is going to be an increase in profits for her business. This, she says, will improve the longevity of her business and, most important, enable her to give her kids a better education.

loans.use: The purchase of more fish for resale

loans.name: Baby Rose

texts.en: Baby Rose S. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Kawayanan, Brgy Vito, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: buying and selling seashells and an electronic reloading business. Her husband, Gary S., who is 37 years old, works as a security guard to earn his living. They have two children who are 1 and 10 years old. Baby Rose joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Baby Rose has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 19,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,000 PHP, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing 19,500 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase more seashells to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future to meet their daily needs. Baby Rose S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more seashells to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita P. is a married woman who lives in Sitio. Hiyang-hiyang, Barangay Patag, Silay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a pig fattening business and a charcoal selling business. Her husband, Domingueto P., who is 46 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 21 and 31 years old. 

Merlita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Merlita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 25,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of $575, raising the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing 25,000 PHP again, which she intends to use to buy inventory to sell in her general store so that she can continue to earn and save up for future expansion of her businesses. Merlita P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jose Humberto

texts.es:
Don José de 58 años de edad, es casado y vive junto a su esposa y 5 hijos, la mayor de 14 años de edad y la menor de 5 años, ellos residen en el cantón la Laguna, caserío los G. de Corinto en Morazán. José se dedica a la siembra de hortalizas y la crianza de ganado, el aprendió la siembra de hortalizas desde que era muy pequeño, pues su padre se dedicaba a ese oficio, él no tiene un horario fijo para le siembra, y que a veces le ocasiona problemas las plagas porque le dañan su producción. Hoy don José necesita un crédito el cual invertirá en la siembra de seis tareas de tomate y tres tareas de chile, comprando los materiales necesarios como es la semilla, abono y el tratamiento para plagas.
Este crédito ayudara a don José a mejorar su cosecha, a obtener mejores hortalizas sanas para su comercialización y para el consumo familiar y así que sus ingresos familiares sean mayores.
Sus sueños son obtener una buena producción que le permita tener mejores ingresos para poder ayudar a su familia y mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
José, 58 years old, is married and lives with his wife and five children. The oldest daughter is 14 years old and the youngest is 5. They live in the Laguna canton, in the Los G. de Corinto hamlet in the town of Morazan. Jose plants vegetables and raises cattle. He learned to plant vegetables when he was very young because his father was also in the same activity. He does not have a fixed schedule to plant. Sometimes he has issues with plagues damaging his crop. Currently Jose needs a loan to invest in planting six lots of tomatoes and three lots of peppers by buying the necessary material such as seeds, fertilizer and treatment for plagues. This loan will help Jose improve his harvest, obtain better vegetables to sell and for his family's consumption and to increase his family's income. His dream is to obtain a better harvest which would help him have more income to help his family and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer and seeds to plant vegetables

loans.name: Rosaura

texts.es:
Rosaura es una señora de 51 años, es madre soltera y vive junto a sus 3 hijas, la mayor de 18 años y la menor de 7 años, residen en Corinto, Morazán. Ella se dedica a la venta de cosméticos, dicha actividad la realiza durante toda la semana en las zonas cercanas a su vivienda, sin tener un horario fijo.
Doña Rosaura está solicitando un préstamo que invertirá en la compra de mas productos como lociones, cremas y labiales. Este préstamo la ayudara a aumentar su negocio y a ofrecer diferentes productos que le permitirán generar los ingresos para solventar las necesidades básicas de la familia.
Los sueños son que a través del trabajo y el negocio pueda ayudar a las hijas a terminar los estudios.
texts.en:
Rosaura is a 51-year-old woman who is single and lives with her 3 daughters. The eldest is 18 and the youngest 7 years old. They live in Corinto, Morazan. Rosaura sell cosmetics every day in the zones near her house without a fixed schedule. Rosaura is soliciting a loan to invest in buying more products, like lotions, creams, and lipstick. The loan will help her to increase business, offer different products, and permit the generation of more income to pay for the basic necessities of her family. Rosaura's dream is that by means of her work and the business, she might be able to help her daughters complete their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING MORE PRODUCTS LIKE LOTIONS, CREAMS, AND LIPSTICK TO SELL

loans.name: Eugenio

texts.es:
Eugenio es un señor de 28 años de edad, reside en el caserío la guaruma en Yamabal, Morazán, vive junto a su esposa y dos hijos de 5 y 3 años de edad, él se dedica a la agricultura porque desde pequeño su padre le enseño a trabajar la tierra sembrando Maíz y frijol, su jornada normal de trabajo es de seis de la mañana a una de la tarde.
Don Eugenio está solicitando un crédito el cual invertirá en la compra de fertilizante para abonar su siembra y asi obtener una buena producción. Este crédito ayudara a don Eugenio a mejorar sus cultivos y obtener una mejor cosecha, que ayude a solventar sus necesidades familiares.
Su sueño es trabajar la tierra y que cada vez su cosecha sea mejor para poder algún día comprar un lugar donde vivir con su familia mejorando sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Eugenio, 28, lives in La Guaruma, in Yamabal, Morazán, with his wife and two sons who are 5 and 3 years old. He has been a farmer since he was little and his father taught him how to work the land planting corn and beans. His normal work day is from 6am until 1pm. Eugenio is asking for funds to buy fertilizers to fertilize his crops in order to get a good crop yield. This loan will help Eugenio improve his crops and get a better harvest that will help him meet family needs. His dream is to work the land and that each successive harvest is better so that one day he can buy a place to live with his family thus improving their living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to plant corn and beans.

loans.name: Bwavumpologoma Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
Eva N. belongs to Bwavumpologoma Women’s group-Lugazi.  Eva has been a hard worker with entrepreneur skills ever since she began her food sell business 4 years ago in Kiyoola-Lugazi. She began this business under the auspices of her close friend who often told her she was destined for success. In retrospect she says she was living by her wits being a housewife. Circumstances have taken a favorable turn for this widowed mother of 5 as she is now able to live within the ways and means provided by her business. 

She has been selling  mostly staple foods for families in Uganda like bananas, sweet potatoes and fish. 180,000 shillings a month is what her business generates for her. With this loan, Eva is upbeat she will be able to purchase more bags of these foods that she will resell and at length, make more profits.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of staple foods like bananas and sweet potatoes for resell

loans.name: Maria Salvadora

texts.es:
María tiene 26 años D. edad, vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos D. 4 y 2 años D. edad, residen en el barrio el calvario D. Guatajiagua en Morazán, ella se dedica a la elaboración D. Comales D. barro, oficio que aprendió por su abuela quien le enseño desD. muy pequeña, su trabajo lo inicia desD. las siete D. la mañana hasta las seis D. la tarD..
María está solicitando un crédito que utilizara para la compra D. barro que es la materia prima para su negocio, al igual que comprar comales en otros pequeños negocios para después comercializarlos y ver la posibilidad D. tener una ganancia.
Este crédito le beneficiará para el crecimiento D. su negocio e incrementar sus ingresos que ayuden a solventar sus necesidades y las D. su familia.
Sus aspiraciones son poseer un negocio estable, mayores ingresos para poder iniciar la construcción D. una casa más segura y mejorar las condiciones D. vida D. la familia.
texts.en:
María, 26, lives with her husband and two children who are 4 and 2 years of age in El Calvario D. Guatajiagua, Morazán. She makes clay comales (a smooth, flat griddle typically used in Latin America to cook tortillas, toast spices, sear meat, and generally prepare food), a skill she learned from her grandmother who taught her how to make them when she was still a little girl. She starts her work day at 7am and goes until 7pm. María is asking for a loan to buy the clay that’s her main raw ingredient for her business as well as to buy some comales in other small businesses to later resell and see if she might earn additional profits. The loan will be of use for her business’ growth and increase her income that will help her meet household and family needs. Her goals are to have a stable business, increased income in order to start to build a safer home and improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clay to make earthenware Comales (a smooth, flat griddle typically used in Latin America to cook tortillas, toast spices, sear meat, and generally prepare food).

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna P. is a married woman who lives in Brgy Cervantes, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a Carenderia or eatery  business.  Her husband Nonilo P., who is 41 years old, works as a Carpenter and Plumber to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 4 children who are 3 to 20 years old. 

Edna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Edna has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 20000, which she intends to use to purchase of raw food ingredients to cook and sell in her carenderia or eatery so that she could continue to earn and  save up for future for the education of her children. Edna P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Plaxeda

texts.en:
Plaxeda N. lives in the Namungoona neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (grand children). 

Plaxeda has a business of selling green bananas.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Plaxeda works in Kasubi Market and uses public transport to and from work. She sells both on retail and wholesale. Plaxeda has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of green bananas. The main business challenge(s) for Plaxeda include seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to construct rental rooms and going to villages for bananas.   Plaxeda lives in a home that she owns and she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses include food, transport from home to the market and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 47 years old and married with two children, aged 23 and 20.  She is a devoted and hardworking lady who runs a shop where she sells bags.  She has ten years of experience in her business.  Thanks to Faulu Kenya for helping her to attain business management skills. She hopes to expand her business in the future.  Rose has requested for 50, 000 Kes to buy handbags and school bags.

loans.use: To buy handbags and school bags

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne is 30 years old, married and has a two-year-old child.  For three years, she has been running Hope medical clinic to earn a living.  Her business is located in the slums hence most of her customers are low-income earners.  She has been running her business with one employee.  She says that she joined Faulu Kenya in the Kingstone Self Help group. 

She has seen a big improvement in her business especially after completing her first loan.  She adds that she is aiming to achieve more with Faulu Kenya.  She has requested for 40, 000 Kes to decorate her clinic so as to attract more customers.  In five years, she sees herself having a very big business premise.

loans.use: To decorate her clinic to attract more customers

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina B. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Cagay, Brgy Buenavista, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: selling ready to wear clothes and direct-selling of Natasha products, a popular low-cost line of personal care products. Her husband Ismael B. Jr., who is 40 years old, works as a Baker to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 5 children who are 3 to 20 years old. 

Gina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1994 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19500, which she intends to use to purchase of more product to sell so that she could continue to save up for future house improvements. Gina B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: purchase more Ready To Wear clothing and Personal Products to resell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria D. is a 46-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a sari-sari (general) store business.  She lives in Prk. Santan I, Brgy Old Sagay, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1998 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari (general) store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP 4000. 

Gloria is now borrowing PHP 15000 so that she could  purchase more products to sell in her Sari-sari store.  This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gloria aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well eing by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en: Having ventured into the business of cattle, hard working  Wilson T. has no regrets from listening to  the advice he got from friends to start his current business which he operates from Musaana, Rukungiri. In his culture, in western Uganda, people own large heads of cattle This 40 year old has benefited a lot from his farming business. He deals in selling cattle for hides, skins and beef,  products he gets from his cattle business. His motive to acquire this loan is to help buys sprays for cattle to kill ticks and also de-worming medicine to treat against diseases that affect the cattle. This will help him increase production as well as revenue as he  looks to further restock more cows on the farm.

loans.use: To Buy more cows to raise

loans.name: Grupo Solidario Trabajando Juntas Group

texts.es: Grupo Solidario Trabajando Juntas está integrado por 2 socias (Gladis y), las cuales residen en diferentes barrios de Juticalpa y realizan diferentes actividades económicas. La coordinadora del grupo es Gladys Yolanda C., tiene 48 años, es madre soltera de dos hijos de 12 y 26 años. Inició a trabajar desde una edad muy temprana ya que le gustaba cocinar. Ella tiene una pequeña caseta donde vende todo tipo de golosinas como ser tajaditas, yuca con chicharrón, pastelitos, baleadas, tortillas con quesillo, plátano con carne, empanadas, etc. Su horario de atención es de Lunes a Domingo desde las 6:00 am hasta las 9:00 pm. Una de sus ventajas es que la ubicación del negocio es cerca de la terminal de buses y es muy frecuente la concurrencia de personas. Un desafío personal que está enfrentando es la perdida reciente de su madre. El préstamo lo necesita para invertirlo en la compra de verduras, maseca, quesillo, papas, refrescos, platos, vasos, tenedores,  salsas, condimentos, todo para su negocio.  Con esto espera obtener las suficientes ganancias para ahorrar y comprar una casa porque donde vive actualmente es alquilado y el pago es muy caro.
texts.en:
The “Trabajando Juntas” (Working Together) communal bank has two members (Gladis and Maria Esperanza) who live in different neighborhoods in Juticalpa and are in different commercial activities. The group Coordinator is Gladys Yolanda C., 48. She is a single mother of two children who are 12 and 26 years of age. She started working at a very young age because she enjoyed cooking. She has a small stand where she sells all kinds of snacks like: tajaditas (sautéed sweet plantains), yucca con chicharrón [The yuca (cassava) is served with raw cabbage with lemon. On top of the cabbage, chicharrones which are deep fried seasoned pork fat and skin, tomato hot sauce and Mojo (not to be confused with the Mojito cocktail), made with oil, garlic, onion, spices such as oregano and bitter orange or lime juice], little cakes, baleadas (one of the most common street foods in Honduras. It is basically made up of a flour tortilla which is folded and filled with refried mashed beans, quesillo or Parmesan cheese and sour cream. Many people however add to the baleadas roast meat or scrambled eggs to taste), tortillas with cheese, plantain with meat, turnovers, etc. Her work schedule is Monday to Sunday from 6am until 9pm. One of the business’ advantages is its location because it’s near the bus terminal and therefore has lots of foot traffic. A personal challenge she is facing is the recent loss of her mother. She needs the loan to invest in the purchase of vegetables, corn meal, cheese, potatoes, beverages, dishes, drinking glasses, forks, sauces and condiments-everything for her business. She hopes to earn sufficient profits to be able to have some savings and buy a house because she currently rents and the rental is very expensive.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products to make snacks.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 30 years old and married with one child.  He distributes bread and milk to small and medium traders including hotels. He has been engaged in the business for seventeen years.  His business is located in the slum settings within Lenana Village.  He has managed to employ one person.  

For financial support, Peter joined the  Unity Self Help group in Faulu Kenya.  He had previously taken out loans amounting to 210, 000 Kes through the group.  Now, Peter has started becoming a stable business-man and a responsible father.  He has requested for a loan of 50, 000 Kes to purchase a plot for future construction of a bread-making bakery.  He dreams of becoming a successful business-man with a number of bakeries in the country. Peter says that he is a young, hardworking and energetic man who likes rendering services to people.

loans.use: To purchase a plot for future construction of a bread-making bakery

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca B. lives in the Makerere neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has  5 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (her sister).  Rebecca has a business, selling shoes. She has been in this business for 4 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Rebecca sells her products at the market by means of retail.   

Rebecca has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more pairs of shoes. She also generates additional income through teaching. The main business challenge(s) for Rebecca include seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are  to start importing shoes. Rebecca lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, paying electricity bills and  medication.

loans.use: To buy more pairs of shoes

loans.name: Davis

texts.en: Davis is a member of Pamoja Entrepreneurs group in Faulu Kenya.  He joined the group as an entrepreneur who sells books, stationery and offers computer services.  He sells stationery supplies such as books and pens.  Since he became part of Faulu Kenya, he has managed to increase his business.  He had previously taken out a loan from Faulu Kenya.  Now, he is requesting 80,000 KES to buy more books.  He hopes to expand his market niche in the future.  He dreams of stabilizing his business and diversifying into other products.

loans.use: To buy books

loans.name: Heide

texts.en:
Heide D. is a married woman who lives in Hda. Rosario, Poblacion II, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by fruit vending.  Her husband, Wennie D., who is 55 years old, earns an income as a security guard.  They have three children who are 16 to 30 years old, with two of their children having their own families and only one living at home to help Heide in her business activity. 

Heide joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 9 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Heide has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP, which she added to her own capital, helped her earn a monthly profit of $1184, raising the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 10th cycle loan, she is borrowing 19,000 PHP again to supplement her own capital so that she can buy more fruits to sell. Heide is working hard so that she can sustain her family's daily needs and be able to save up for the education of her youngest child, and to set aside some money for the future security of her family. Heide D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: purchase fruits in season to sell

loans.name: Grupo Solidario Flor De Cayo Blanco Group

texts.es: Grupo Solidario Flor de Cayo Blanco está integrado por 2 socios (Omar e Iris), los cuales residen en la Aldea de Cayo Blanco y realizan diferentes actividades económicas. El coordinador del grupo es Omar Antonio A., tiene 42 años y su familia está conformada por su esposa y sus tres hijos de 19, 17 y 16 años. Omar se dedica a la compra y venta de cerdos. Inició su negocio a raíz de su casamiento porque tuvo que salirse de la casa de sus padres y para poder mantener a su esposa tuvo que buscar una forma de hacerlo, así que comenzó a comprar cerdos para destazarlos y vender la carne a pulperías y carnicerías. Una de las ventajas es que es un negocio muy rentable y eso le ha permitido sostener a su familia, aunque con muchas limitaciones económicas. Una de las desventajas es que el mercado está saturado de personas que se dedican al mismo negocio y algunos para vender su producto más rápido lo hacen a un precio muy bajo con el cual no puede competir.  Con el apoyo de este préstamo espera tener las suficientes ganancias para llevar el sustento al hogar y comprar los útiles, uniformes, zapatos  que sus hijos necesitan para ir al colegio. Su compañera de grupo Iris se dedica a la venta de golosinas, es casada y tiene dos hijos.
texts.en:
The “Flor de Cayo Blanco” communal bank has two members (Omar and Iris) who live in the village of Cayo Blanco and carry out different economic activities. The group coordinator is Omar Antonio A., 42. His family consists of his wife and his three children who are 19, 17, and 16 years old. Omar is a pork merchant. He started his business when he got married because he had to leave his parents’ house and had to find a way to support his wife. He started buying pigs to butcher and sell the meat to grocery stores and butcheries. One of the advantages of the business is that it is very profitable and this has allowed him to support his family although with many economic limitations. One of the disadvantages is that the market is saturated with people who do the same kind of work and some of them, in order to sell their products quickly, do so at such low prices that he is unable to compete. With the support this loan gives him he hopes to have sufficient profits to support his household and to buy school supplies, uniforms and shoes that his children need to go to school. His fellow group member, Iris, sells snacks. She is married and has two children

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita C. is a 58-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store, a food vending business and a transportation (tricycle) business. She lives in Prk. Mahogany, Brgy Magsaysay, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard at her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of about $95. Teresita is now borrowing 19,000 PHP so that she can purchase more inventory to sell in her general store and at the same time to fully pay the balance on her motorcycle with sidecar that shuttles passengers in their area for a fee. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 16,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Teresita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:
 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.
 
Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane N. lives in the Makerere neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, three of whom are in school. She also takes care of her brother's daughter.    

Jane has a business of selling newspapers. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works six days out of every week. She sells her products in a shop, by means of retail.  Jane has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more newspapers. The main business challenges for Jane include transportation and the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become an agent for newpapers.  

Jane lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more papers for resale

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa R. is a married woman who lives in Upper Barangay Tubod, Toledo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari (variety) store, P.O Card (cash cards) and a Natasha dealership (selling shoes, apparel, accessories and personal care products by catalog order). Her husband, Cirilo R., who is 50 years old, helps his wife in running the business. They have four children, ranging in age from 24 to 29. 

Elsa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Elsa  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $100, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 19th cycle loan, she is borrowing 10,000 PHP again, to purchase inventory to sell in her sari-sari store and to buy more p.o cards to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future, to continue her businesses and to expand them for a lifetime. Elsa R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory to sell

loans.name: Grupo Solidario Mi Pequeño Esfuerzo Group

texts.es: Grupo Solidario Mi Pequeño Esfuerzo está integrado por 3 socias (Ángela, Iris y Maria), las cuales residen en diferentes barrios del municipio de La Unión y realizan diferentes actividades económicas. La coordinadora del grupo es Ángela Margarita F., tiene 56 años, es madre soltera de cuatro hijos de las siguientes edades 37, 28, 27 y 22 años. Ella es una persona luchadora,  que se levanta muy temprano todos los días desde hace 4 años para ir a trabajar a su puesto de verduras ubicado frente al parque central de la comunidad. Es una persona muy conocida y cuenta con buenas referencias de parte de sus clientes y compañeras de grupo. Con el apoyo del préstamo espera surtir de más y variadas verduras de la temporada. Su meta es mejorar el estilo de vida de ella y su familia. Su compañera de grupo Iris necesita el préstamo para invertirlo en su puesto de golosinas y María invertirlo en la compra un fardo de ropa de segunda mano y tener más y variados estilos que estén a la moda. Hace 5 años son clientes de FAMA y con los préstamos obtenidos han podido tener una fuente de ingresos que les permite llevar el sustento a sus hogares.
texts.en:
The village bank Mi Pequeño Esfuerzo (My Little Effort) is composed of 3 members (Ángela, Iris y Maria) who live in different neighborhoods in the city of La Unión and work at different trades. The coordinator of the group is Ángela Margarita F.. She is 56 years old, a single mother, and has four children who are 37, 28, 27, and 22 years old respectively. She is hard-working. She has risen very early every day for the past four years to go to work at her vegetable stall, which is located at the front of the central park of the community. She is well-known and has good references from her customers and the members of her village bank. With the help of this loan, she hopes to purchase a greater quantity and variety of seasonal vegetables. Her goal is to improve the standard of living of herself and her family. Her companion from the bank, Iris, needs this loan for investment in her stall, which sells sweets; and Maria will invest in a bundle of second-hand clothing and will have more clothing and varied styles that are currently popular. They have been customers of FAMA (local lending institution) for five years, and their previous loans have helped them obtain a source of income, which has permitted them to bring sustenance to their homes.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de verduras

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina B. is a widow  who lives in Purok Katipunan, Barangay Maquiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and a pig fattening business. She has four children who are 18 to 28 years old, one of whom already has a family, while the remaining three who live at home either have their own jobs or attend school. 

Paulina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1996 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Paulina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of approximately $230, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing 19,500 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell in her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future and for her children's higher education. Paulina B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca G. is a married woman who lives in Sitio. Bulobito-on, Barangay Miranda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a fish vending business. Her husband, Antonio G., who is 67 years old, earns his living as a fish vendor, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who are 5 to 18 years old. 

Rebecca joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rebecca has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 14,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $103, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing 12,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more inventory to sell in her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Rebecca G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory to sell

loans.name: Sol Y Esperanza Group

texts.en:
The communal bank “Sol y Esperanza” (Sun and Hope) consists of sixteen associates from Santiago’s Puente Alto district. These individuals' livelihoods consist mainly of store sales, clothing sales, the manufacture of leather crafts, cooking and selling homemade bread, pies, empanadas, and handmade knitted items. 

Angela is the president of the group. In the photo she can be found in the furthest row above, and third from the left. She has been selling used clothing for the past two years in a kiosk at two fairs close to her house.  Before this she sold articles of leather; for example, coin purses, wallets and cigarette cases, among other things. She decided to change her merchandise to test sales, and thankfully it has gone very well. Angela is also the mother of a seven-year-old boy. 

Angela dreams of having her own home in two more years, and to install a business of fast food and a small grocery store.
 
She has enjoyed working with Kiva partner, Fondo Esperanza, as it has motivated her interaction with other entrepreneurs within the communal bank and with the loan officer.  In addition, she receives entrepreneurial training where she learns to administer her accounts, expenses and earnings. 

Puente Alto is a community in northern Santiago, the capital of Chile.  Puente Alto has nearly 500,000 inhabitants and it is expected to continue growing.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing to resell

loans.name: Edith Marisol

texts.es:
Doña Edith es una señora que vive en Usulután con sus dos hijos y un nieto, ella es madre soltera y sus hijos dependen económicamente de ella. Su oficio es la venta de tortillas y lo inicio cuando hace muchos años dedicando un horario desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 3 de la tarde. 
Ella solicita un préstamo que invertirá en la compra de Maíz y Gas para tener como provisión del negocio y poder comprarlo a un menor precio porque lo hará por mayor. Esta inversión ayudara a que Edith reciba mejores ingresos que le ayuden a solventar necesidades que a diario enfrenta con su familia.
La aspiración de ella es tener un negocio fuerte que le brinde lo necesario y pueda sacar a su familia adelante con una mejor vida a futuro.
texts.en:
Doña Edith Is a woman who lives in Usultán with her two children and a grandson. She is a single mother, and her children are economically dependent on her. Her trade is selling tortillas; she began this trade many years ago with a schedule of work that starts at 7 in the morning and ends at 3 in the afternoon. The requested loan will be invested in corn and gas for business use. She will be able to buy these items at a lower price because she will be buying at wholesale. This investment will increase Edith's earnings and help her to pay for daily necessities for her family. Her goal is to have a strong business that enables her to pay for necessities and offer a better future to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn to make tortillas

loans.name: Brenda Lisseth

texts.es:
Brenda vive con su madre y dos hermanas, tiene un negocio de cosméticos y al mismo tiempo vende cocteles de conchas de mar. Ella aprendió este negocio desde que tenía 10 años pues su madre se dedicaba a este tipo de comercio, pero Brenda se esforzó por tener su propio negocio y es así como lo logro trabajando todos los días de la semana. 
Ella está solicitando un crédito que invertirá en la compra de mercadería para aumentar su negocio. Con esta inversión hará crecer su capital de trabajo teniendo más posibilidades de obtener mayores ganancias.
Su principal aspiración es que el negocio sea más estable y le brinde los ingresos necesarios para cubrir las necesidades y mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Brenda lives with her mother and two sisters. She has a cosmetics business and also sells seafood cocktails. Brenda learned this business at the age of 10 since her mother engaged in the same type of work. However, Brenda struggled to start her own business but now she is able to work every day of the week.

She is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of merchandise to increase her business. This investment will increase her operating capital, which will provide her additional possibilities to earn more income. Her main aspiration is to have a more stable business that will generate the income required to cover her necessities and improve her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics

loans.name: Claudia Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Claudia de 36 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene una hija y vive junto a su madre en Usulután. Se dedica al negocio y posee una tienda donde vende granos básicos y artículos de primera necesidad como frijol, arroz, azúcar; este negocio lo inicio su madre por iniciativa propia desde hace 20 años y que hoy día administra Claudia con un horario de 6 de la mañana a 7:30 de la noche, las ventas son regulares por lo que desea invertir más para poder ofrecer a sus clientes.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo el cual invertirá en la compra de Arroz, Maíz, frijol, aceite y otros productos que necesita en su negocio.
Este crédito ayudara a Doña Claudia ya que aumentara su capital de trabajo,  con esta inversión crecerá su negocio, también serán mayores las ventas y las ganancias obteniendo mayores ingresos que ayuden a sustentar las necesidades familiares.
Los sueños de ella son mantener un negocio estable por muchos años, desarrollarse dentro del mercado y mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Claudia, 36, is a single mother. She has a daughter and lives with her mother in Usulután. She is a businesswoman and has a store where she sells basic grains and basic need items like: beans, rice and sugar. The business was started by her mother through her own initiative 20 years ago. Claudia now runs it and her work schedule is from 6am until 7:30pm. Sales are regular so she wants to invest more in order to have more to offer her customers. She is asking for a loan to buy rice, corn, beans, cooking oil and other products she needs in her store. This loan will help Claudia because it will increase her working capital and the investment will enlarge her business. Sales will increase and so will profits which will help her meet family needs. Her dreams are to keep her business stable for many years, to develop within the marketplace and to have better living conditions for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, beans and cooking oil for the business.

loans.name: Jose Valentin

texts.es:
Don José es un señor de 52 años de edad, reside en San Rafael Oriente de San Miguel junto a su esposa y dos hijas una de 18 y la otra de 20 años de edad, quienes dependen económicamente de él. Don José es agricultor dedicándose a este trabajo desde joven el cual lo aprendió por sus patrones que le enseñaron a la siembra de Maíz, no posee horario de trabajo y actualmente tiene la dificultad de contar con capital para la siembra y ayudar a la familia con los gastos.
Él necesita un Préstamo para la compra de materiales agrícolas como Maíz, Abono y fertilizantes, para poder realizar el cultivo.
Este préstamo le será de mucha ayuda pues contara con los recursos necesarios para hacer un buen trabajo con la tierra, con el único inconveniente seria  que ocurra algún desastre natural y dañe sus cultivos, de lo contrario el obtendrá una mejor cosecha ya que le brindara los cuidados necesarios  y obtendrá mayores ingresos que solventen los gastos familiares.
Su sueño es sacar a su familia adelante, bríndales una mejor calidad de vida y buen desarrollo en la educación de sus hijas.
texts.en:
José, 52, lives in San Rafael Oriente, San Miguel with his wife and two daughters who are 18 and 20 years of age and depend on him economically. José is a farmer. He’s been farming from a very young age ever since he learned from his bosses how to plant corn. He doesn’t have a fixed work schedule and he currently is facing difficulties in having capital available to plant and help his family meet their expenses. He needs a loan in order to buy farming supplies like corn, manure and fertilizers in order to plant. The loan will be of great use to him because he will have the necessary resources to do a good job with the land. The only problem would be if some natural disaster were to occur that would damage his crops. Otherwise, he will obtain a good harvest because he will provide proper care thus obtaining higher income to meet family expenses. His dream is to have his family succeed, to provide them with a better quality of life and to see his daughters’ education unfold properly.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn, manure and fertilizers.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Rosa Etelvina

texts.es:
Rosa es una joven de 24 años de edad, vive junto a su madre y un hermano, es soltera y no tiene hijos, ellos residen en la colonia Punta Diamante de Usulután, Ella trabaja junto a su madre administrando el negocio de venta de Ropa al por mayor, ella aprendió el comercio de Ropa por su tía, quien se dedica también a este tipo de comercio, Rosa ya tiene 8 años de poseer su propio negocio.
Hoy ella necesita un préstamo para la compra de mercadería y así surtir su negocio, invirtiendo este préstamo en la compra de 10 fardos de ropa. Dicha inversión ayudara a que Rosa junto a su madre puedan tener un negocio más estable, que poco a poco crezca dentro del mercado, dándoles los ingresos que necesitan para cubrir sus necesidades, obteniendo mayores ventas y mayores ganancias.
El sueño de Rosa es poseer un negocio grande y fuerte en la venta de ropa mejorando las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Rosa, 24, is a young woman living with her mother and brother. She’s single and has no children. She lives in Usulután’s Punta Diamante neighborhood. She works alongside her mother running a wholesale clothing business. She learned the business from her aunt who is in this line of work also. Rosa has had her own business for 8 years now. Today she needs a loan to buy stock items for her business. She will use the loan to buy 10 bundles of clothing. This investment will help Rosa and her mother have a more stable business that can gradually grow in the marketplace giving them the income they need to meet their needs, obtaining higher sales and greater profits. Rosa’s dream is to have a large store and, strong in clothing sales, be able to improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. buys bags of gari (a couscous-like grain made from grated cassava) and sells the gari in smaller quantities at Elmina.

Ama has received junior high education. She is married to a mason and has five dependents. She supports her husband in the general upkeep of the home.

Ama’s loan will be used to buy additional bags of gari to sell to her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to build a storehouse.

loans.use: To buy additional bags of gari to sell

loans.name: Pyillis

texts.en:
Pyillis D. is a single parent with two children. Her ex-husband is a mason. She has been through senior high school.

Pyillis sells pastries and biscuits at Elmina and uses her income to educate and feed her family. She will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to prepare pastries for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans of reinvesting in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients to prepare pastries for sale

loans.name: Cornelio

texts.es:
Cornelio  tiene 55 anos, esta casado con Isabel Cubilla de 57 años   tienen  cinco hijos todos mayores de edad, tres de los cuales trabaja con él en su fábrica de costura.
Su esposa le ayuda en el hogar en los que haceres domesticos, Cornelio aprendió el oficio en la Argentina donde estuvo trabajando por más de 10 años en ese pais, de donde trajo capital suficiente para habilitar su propia fabrica de costura en su casa y así quedarse con su familia.
Actualmente trabaja con él tres hijos y dos sobrinos a quienes les enseña el oficio y a la vez les remunera por los servicios.
Necesita el crédito para la compra de una máquina de coser.
texts.en:
Cornelio is 55 years old and is married to Isabel Cubilla who is 57. They have five children who are all adults. Three of them work with him in his sewing factory. His wife helps him in the home with the housework. Cornelio learned his trade in Argentina where he was working for more than ten years and from where he earned enough money to enable his own sewing factory in his home and allow him to stay with his family. Currently, he works with his three children and two nephews who he is teaching to sew and at the same time paying for their services. He needs the loan to purchase an additional sewing machine.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine for his work.

loans.name: Jamilatu

texts.en:
Jamilatu W. is married to a carpenter and lives with her husband and two children. She has no formal educational background.

Jamilatu sells provisions at Elmina. She will use the loan to purchase extra provisions to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to set up another provisions shop in Abura market.

loans.use: To purchase extra provisions to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama D. is a widow taking care of six dependents. She has not acquired any form of education.

Ama sells bags of charcoal at Elmina and uses her income in providing the basic needs of the family such as food, clothing and shelter. She will use the loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to meet the demand of her customers.

With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to save to complete her storehouse.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to meet the demand of her customers

loans.name: Atta

texts.en:
Atta K. sells charcoal and firewood at Elmina. She has received junior high education. She is married to a security man and has four children.

Atta has been selling charcoal and firewood for five years now and supports her husband in taking care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy additional bags of charcoal for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy additional bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Hawa M. sells bags of water, biscuits and other things in Elmina. Hawa has received a senior high school education. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a mason. She responsibly helps her husband look after the general welfare of the home. Her loan will be used to buy additional goods to sell. She hopes to save the new profits from her business to further her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy additional goods to sell

loans.name: San Cayetano Ii Group

texts.es:
